Rate of Speech:
Complete running speech tasks, which may include:
1) Observation of conversational/informal speech (e.g., "What does a typical day look like for you?")
2) Narrative task: Describe an image (e.g., the Kite Picture or Cookie Theft picture).
3) Reading task (e.g., the Grandfather Passage or Caterpillar Passage).
Fluency & Cadence: Refer to "Rate of Speech" tasks (Observation, Narrative, and Reading).
Loudness: Refer to "Rate of Speech" tasks (Observation, Narrative, and Reading).
Voice Quality and Respiration:
Observe during other speech tasks. Measure maximum phonation time:
Ask the patient, "Take a deep breath and hold out the sound 'ah' for as long as you can."
Word & Phrasal Stress:
Observe during other speech tasks.
Optional additional task: Present patient with a sentence in writing: "The deadline is tomorrow." Ask, "Read this sentence with a different stress. For example, 'The deadline IS tomorrow.'"
Articulation:
1) Repeat words: "northwest, twist, fused, sleeps, scarecrow, playground, lifeboat, shipwreck, mushroom, woodwork." (Tikofsky, 1970)
2) Repeat sentences: "A strong job interview actually breathes life into my morning." "The other difficult colleague will perhaps confront my behavior and enjoy it." (Gurevich & Kim, 2023)
3) Automatic speech: "Tell me the days of the week."
Resonance:
Check for nasal emission using a mirror OR ask: "Repeat after me: 'Buy Bobby a puppy.' Now, pinch your nostrils shut. Again, 'Buy Bobby a puppy.'"
Repeat with: "My mama makes lemon muffins."
Compare resonance when the nares are not occluded versus occluded.
Diadochokinetic Rate (DDK):
Record to measure repetitions per second if possible.
AMR: "Take a breath and repeat 'puh-puh-puh' as fast and steadily as you can until I tell you to stop." Provide an example. Perform additional trials to test maximum performance.
SMR: "Repeat 'puh-tuh-kuh' over and over until I tell you to stop." Alternative: "buttercup".
Expression: Observe emotional state throughout. Note any reports of uncontrolled or inappropriate emotional responses.
OME (Face):
"Relax and look straight ahead. Open your lips and breathe quietly."
Look at the jaw and lips at rest.
OME (Jaw):
1) Resistance: "Open wide; don't let me close your mouth." / "Close your mouth; don't let me open it."
2) Movement: "Bite down five times, like you're chewing gum."
OME (Lips):
1) Smile: "Smile and hold for three seconds."
2) Resistance: "Don't let me move your lips." / "Squeeze your lips tightly together; don't let me open them."
OME (Soft Palate):
1) "Puff your cheeks up with air."
2) "Open your mouth wide." (Observe palate at rest using a tongue blade).
OME (Tongue):
1) Protrusion: "Stick your tongue straight out. Hold for three seconds."
2) Resistance: "Don't let me push your tongue back."
3) Movement: "Curl your tongue up towards your nose, then down towards your chin."
4) Lateral Strength: "Push your tongue into the inside of your cheek against my finger."
Body Movement: Observe ambulation and motor movements (e.g., reaching, writing). Reference PT/OT notes.
